messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Provably Efficient Offline Goal-Conditioned Reinforcement Learning with General Function Approximation and Single-Policy Concentrability

Paper Abstract: Abstract Goal-conditioned reinforcement learning (GCRL) refers to learning general-purpose skills that aim to reach diverse goals. In particular, offline GCRL only requires purely pre-collected datasets to perform training tasks without additional interactions with the environment. Although offline GCRL has become increasingly prevalent and many previous works have demonstrated its empirical success, the theoretical understanding of efficient offline GCRL algorithms is not well established, especially when the state space is huge and the offline dataset only covers the policy we aim to learn. In this paper, we provide a rigorous theoretical analysis of an existing empirically successful offline GCRL algorithm. We prove that under slight modification, this algorithm enjoys an O~‚Äã(poly‚Å°(1/œµ))~ùëÇpoly1italic-œµ\tilde{O}(\operatorname{poly}(1/\epsilon)) sample complexity (where œµitalic-œµ\epsilon is the desired suboptimality of the learned policy) with general function approximation thanks to the property of (semi-)strong convexity of the objective functions. We only require nearly minimal assumptions on the dataset (single-policy concentrability) and the function class (realizability). Moreover, this algorithm consists of two uninterleaved optimization steps, which we refer to as VùëâV-learning and policy learning, and is computationally stable since it does not involve minimax optimization. We also empirically validate our theory by showing that the modified algorithm outperforms the previous algorithm in various real-world environments. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first algorithm that is both provably efficient with general function approximation and single-policy concentrability, and empirically successful without requiring solving minimax optimization problems.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Reinforcement learning: Theory and algorithms",
        "Fitted Q-iteration in continuous action-space mdps",
        "Learning near-optimal policies with bellman-residual minimization based fitted policy iteration and a single sample path",
        "Actionable models: Unsupervised offline reinforcement learning of robotic skills",
        "Information-theoretic considerations in batch reinforcement learning",
        "Adversarially trained actor critic for offline reinforcement learning",
        "The complexity of constrained min-max optimization",
        "Error propagation for approximate policy and value iteration",
        "A kernel loss for solving the Bellman equation",
        "Learning to reach goals via iterated supervised learning",
        "On value functions and the agent-environment boundary",
        "Minimax value interval for off-policy evaluation and policy optimization",
        "Is pessimism provably efficient for offline RL?",
        "Learning to achieve goals",
        "Demodice: Offline imitation learning with supplementary imperfect demonstrations",
        "Batch reinforcement learning",
        "Optidice: Offline policy optimization via stationary distribution correction estimation",
        "Offline reinforcement learning: Tutorial, review, and perspectives on open problems",
        "Settling the sample complexity of model-based offline reinforcement learning",
        "Batch policy learning in average reward Markov decision processes",
        "Neural trust region/proximal policy optimization attains globally optimal policy",
        "Learning latent plans from play",
        "Smodice: Versatile offline imitation learning via state occupancy matching",
        "Vip: Towards universal visual reward and representation via value-implicit pre-training",
        "How far i‚Äôll go: Offline goal-conditioned reinforcement learning via fùëìf-advantage regression",
        "Performance bounds in ‚Ñìpsubscript‚Ñìùëù\\ell_{p}-norm for approximate value iteration",
        "Finite-time bounds for fitted value iteration",
        "Dualdice: Behavior-agnostic estimation of discounted stationary distribution corrections",
        "Algaedice: Policy gradient from arbitrary experience",
        "Multi-goal reinforcement learning: Challenging robotics environments and request for research",
        "Bridging offline reinforcement learning and imitation learning: A tale of pessimism",
        "Optimal conservative offline rl with general function approximation via augmented lagrangian",
        "Universal value function approximators",
        "Approximate policy iteration schemes: A comparison",
        "Pessimistic Q-learning for offline reinforcement learning: Towards optimal sample complexity",
        "Finite time bounds for sampling based fitted value iteration",
        "Pessimistic model-based offline reinforcement learning under partial coverage",
        "Minimax weight and Q-function learning for off-policy evaluation",
        "Empirical Processes in M-estimation, volume 6",
        "Neural policy gradient methods: Global optimality and rates of convergence",
        "Batch value-function approximation with only realizability",
        "Bellman-consistent pessimism for offline reinforcement learning",
        "Rethinking goal-conditioned supervised learning and its connection to offline rl",
        "Towards instance-optimal offline reinforcement learning with pessimism",
        "Near-optimal offline reinforcement learning via double variance reduction",
        "Offline stochastic shortest path: Learning, evaluation and towards optimality",
        "Offline reinforcement learning with realizability and single-policy concentrability",
        "Variational policy gradient method for reinforcement learning with general utilities"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Provably Efficient Offline Goal-Conditioned Reinforcement Learning with General Function Approximation and Single-Policy Concentrability, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
